awd_abstract_narration:
This grant will support meetings of the Pacific Northwest Geometry Seminar (PNGS) to be held at the University of British Columbia, the University of Washington, the University of Oregon, Oregon State University, Portland State University, and Lewis & Clark College, beginning in Spring 2019. PNGS meetings generally feature six invited research talks by leading experts in differential geometry and geometrical analysis. The meetings also include discussion sessions in which the speakers and participants assess the state of various areas in geometry and highlight open problems in these areas.

There are a number of very active researchers in geometry scattered throughout the various colleges and universities involved in the Pacific Northwest Geometry Seminar. PNGS meetings will bring these researchers together for consultation, collaboration, and stimulation of new ideas. A significant number of research programs have been initiated as a result of interactions at past meetings. The PNGS series is especially valuable for graduate students in geometry at the participating universities which have small geometry groups. PNGS meetings give these students an excellent opportunity to see the broader picture of research in geometry. The meetings are also very valuable for the growing number of geometers working at some of the smaller universities in the region, such as Pacific University, Seattle University, and Idaho State University. More information can be found on the conference website: www.math.washington.edu/~lee/PNGS

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Since 1974, researchers who study Geometry have been meeting regularly in a forum that is now called the Pacific Northwest Geometry Seminar.  Annual meetings provide an opportunity for geometers in the region to build community, to share ideas, and to form collaborations with one another. These collaborations have led to original research projects in geometry, as well as improvements in geometry programs at universities and colleges across the Pacific Northwest.

At the annual meeting, the seminar features lectures from a mix of local mathematicians and mathematics researchers from further afield. This format serves to promote the work of local scholars, while creating opportunities for interaction with the broader mathematics community. Seminar organizers also strive to highlight work of younger mathematicians in the region, giving them a platform to showcase their work and helping them become integrated with the existing geometry community. 

The National Science Foundation has been supporting the seminar since 1978. While some NSF support is used to bring outside speakers to the seminar, the primary use of funding is to support the participation of regional geometry researchers, bolstering the strength of geometry research in the region. Most recently, the grant supported seminars at Lewis & Clark College in Portland and at Seattle University in Seattle. Speakers at these seminars came from a variety of regional institutions (University of British Columbia, University of Washington, University of Oregon, Lewis & Clark College, Seattle Pacific) as well as from other North American Institutions (UC Berkeley, UC Riverside, University of Quebec, Stony Brook University, University of Alaska Fairbanks, Dartmouth).

The organizers of the  Pacific Northwest Geometry Seminar are proud to continue the long tradition of geometry meetings in the region, and are grateful for continued support from the NSF.
